bibl.title: Letter from Victor C. Vaughan and Walter Reed to the Surgeon General, March 21, 1899

div1.p: Vaughan and Reed submit a report about their examination of three crematories at Washington Barracks. They ascertain that none of the models submitted by inventors meet all the conditions required by the Army. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Victor C. Vaughan and Walter Reed to the Surgeon General, March 21, 1899
div1.opener:
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS. Camp Crematories
Washington, D. C., March 21, 1899.
To the Surgeon General,
U. S. Army,
Washington, D. C.
General:
div1.p:
The Board of Medical Officers convened per S.O., 194, Par.
40, C.S., Adjutant General's Office, August 18, 1898, had the honor
under date of Dec. 22, 1898, and in compliance with S.O., No. 264,
Par. 67, C.S. Adjutant General's Office, November 8, 1898, of submit-
ting a report relating to the disposal of excreta in military camps,
together with plans and drawings of the apparatus recommended by
the Board. In that report we stated “that methods of incineration
of feces have been and are being investigated, but our practical
examination has not been sufficiently extensive to warrant us in
recommending any of them.”

Since the date of that report we have been able to examine
the practical operation of three crematories which, with the permis-
sion of the Honorable Secretary of War, have been erected for trial
at Washington Barracks, this city. We desire now to report upon
these.

No. 1. The Combined Camp Crematory for excreta and garbage, designed
and submitted by Frederick P. Smith, C.E.

The accompanying circular hereto appended and marked “A”, gives
such a complete description and plan of this Crematory, that we need
add but little thereto. Briefly speaking, it consists of a series
of hoppers arranged in a circle about a central furnace. The urine
2
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
and fecal matter are received upon flat excreta plates, so in-
clined that the fluid parts flow towards the central fire and
are subjected to a constant drying. The solid part of the excreta
is from time to time pushed toward the edge of the fire and when
dried, can at any time, be raked on to the grate and burned.

A large evaporating pan is placed above the fire for the
reception of fluid and solid garbage. When dried sufficiently, the
pan is overturned by means of a lever and the garbage burned.
Sufficient draft and ventilation are secured by means of a pipe,
3 feet in diameter, which rises to a height of about 40 feet.
This Crematory has accomplished, during a trial lasting about
four weeks, all that its inventor has claimed for it, in the matter
of the dessication and subsequent destruction by fire of both ex-
creta and garbage. The closet has been found to be well ventilated
and free of odor whenever inspected by Members of the Board. A mod-
erate fire was sufficient for this purpose. This Crematory appears
to possess durability and is certainly adaptable to any form of
fuel that may be at hand in camp. An advantage possessed by it is
the possibility of applying the flame immediately beneath the ex-
creta plates, in order, if necessary, to hasten the drying and ster-
ilization of the excreta, as well as adjacent parts of the appar-
atus. The fact that, owing to its peculiar construction, the central
fire while drying out the excrement and garbage, does not increase
the temperature of the closet, must be considered as another advant-
age especially in hot climates.

We are not prepared to express the opinion that this
Crematory will entirely prevent the dissemination of the germs of
3
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
typhoid fever by means of flies. Owing to the season of the year,
we have not been able to test the ability of this apparatus to des-
troy all flies entering through the hoppers. We doubt whether
the downward current of air will be sufficient to prevent their
egress, nor are we convinced that they would be destroyed by heat,
if drawn in the oposite direction, for the reason that there appears
to be an upward current of air which is not drawn in immediate
contact with the fire.

While this Crematory is transportable, in the sense that it
consits of a number of pieces of cast-iron joined together by
bolts, and which can be taken apart by ten men in the space of about
five or six hours, and re-erected in about the same time, the fact
must be borne in mind that the weight of an eight hopper apparatus
suitable for a single company is not less than 5200 lbs., and that a
fourteen hopper Crematory for two companies would weigh about 7000
lbs.

In other words, the portability of this apparatus is only
such as would permit of its erection in more or less permanent camps.

No. 2. A Crematory for excreta submitted by the Albany Sanitation
Co., of Albany, N.Y. As erected by Mr. Thos. Hyde, representing the
Company, this Crematory consists of a furnace and 7 closets. Each
closet section is a cylindrical tube, of ¼ inch cast-iron, 20 inches
in diameter and weighing 150 lbs. Rising from each section is a
cast-iron hopper, provided with suitable seat and cover. The separate
closet sections are provided with flanges by means of which the
several sections are securely bolted together, thus forming a contin-
nous iron tube, connected at one end with the furnace. Excreta are
4
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
received into this hollow iron tube.

A galvanized iron pipe, 14 inches in diameter, is pro-
vided for the purpose of bringing a current of warm air from the
furnace and thence conducting it to the distal end of the excreta
tube, from which point it is continually drawn over the surface of
the excreta. This serves both for the purpose of drying the ex-
creta and for the ventilation of the closet.

A urinal is provided, from which the urine is conducted by
means of a 3 inch iron pipe to a pit beneath the furnace, where it
is subjected to constant evaporation. The furnace is furnished with
a smoke stack 16 inches in diameter, rising to a height of about 35
feet. Either wood or coal can be used as fuel. When it becomes
necessary to destroy the accumulation of excreta, pieces of wood or
other combustible material are thrown into the excreta tube and a
fire kindled. The debris remaining after the process of incinera-
tion can be removed by means of a clean-out door placed at the further
end of the tube. This door was not provided in the apparatus sub-
mitted for our inspection; nor was any provision made for the burn-
ing of garbage as shown in the accompanying drawings, which are
hereto appended and marked “Fig. No. 1” and “Fig. No. 2”

During the time of our trial, lasting about three weeks,
this Crematory has accomplished in the matter of good ventilation
and freedom from odors all that was claimed, in this regard, by the
Albany Sanitation Company. It has failed to cause a constant cur-
rant of warm air to pass through the excreta tube and over the
excreta, and hence has not accomplished the drying of the excreta
preparatory to incineration as claimed by the infventors. Practically,
5
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
the deposit or excreta remains in a moist condition and requires
a hot fire for its destruction. The fact that the fire must be ap-
plied to the upper surface of the excreta, not only renders it more
difficult to accomplish its destruction, but prolongs the time re-
quired for its complete incineration.

The remarks made concerning the transportability of the
Smith Crematory will apply equally to this aparatus. While its
weight is estimated to be about 3,000 lbs., the separate closet
sections weigh 150 lbs. and are somewhat unwieldly for the purpose of
handling. The inventors claim, however, that this weight can be much
reduced.

In making a comparison of the foregoing Crematories, we
are of the opinion that as submitted to us for trial, the Smith Cre-
matory possesses certain advantages over that of the Albany Sani-
tation Company. These may be stated as follows.

1st: The constant dessication of both solid and fluid excre-
ta, by the direct radiation of heat from the central fire.
2nd: The simultaneous destruction of garbage.

3rd: The possibility of applying flame immediately beneath
the excreta plates, for the purpose of sterilizing all parts of the
apparatus.

4th: The fact that the furnace fire does not cause any
increased temperature of the closet room.

No. 3: A Crematory for excreta or garbage submitted by the
International Household Garbage and Excrement Crematory Company, of
Buffalo, N.Y.

This consists of a steel jacket lined with asbestos within
6
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
and provided with a sheet iron covering without. The top and bot-
tom of this kjacket consist of cast-iron. The excreta are received
into a cast-iron pot, having a capacity of 7 gallons, and which
revolves on a horizontal axle. A suitable grate, with ash-pit,
is provided beneath the pot. An opening of proper dimensions, with
seat and cover, is provided for in the cast-iron top of the jacket.
Ventilation is brought about by means of a 6 inch stove-pipe flue
rising to a height of 12 feet. The Crematory is fully described
and explained in the pamphlet of the Company, which is hereto append-
ed and marked “B”.

When desired to destroy the contents of the pot, the
wooden seat and cover are removed, the opening closed with a gal-
vanized iron cover provided for that purpose, and a fire started
on the grate below.

In a trial of this Crematory, extending over about one
week, we find that the ventilation is not such as to remove all
offensive odors, when the cover is lifted. This could hardly be
expected. We find that it requires the action of a hot fire for
about two hours, in order to thoroughly reduce the excreta to ashes.
This time can be reduced somewhat by dumping the excreta, as soon
as dried, on the fire beneath. Practically, three hours are required
for the incineration and subsequent cooling of the Crematory.

During the process of incineration, pungent and disagreeable
odors are perceived. This is more perceptible than with the other
Crematories and is probably due to the lesser height at which these
disagreeable odors are liberated into the surrounding air.

This Crematory has the advantage of being transportable
7
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
and ready for use at all times. It does not require to be taken
apart for purposes of transportation, but can be crated and shipped
entire. Its weight is about 330 lbs. When, however, the combined
weight of the number required for a single company, estimated at
eight (8), is taken into consideration, it will be seen that it hardly
falls short of the weight of the other Crematories. If used
for the destruction of garbage, two additional crematories would be
required for each company.

We are of the opinion that during hot weather, this cre-
matory, owing to imperfect ventilation, would be quite offensive.
The quantity of fuel required for incineration must be considered
as an additional and marked disadvantage.

Letters submitted by the inventors setting forth the cost,
weight, &c., of these several crematories, are hereto appended and
marked “C”, “D” and “E”.

In submitting this report the Board desire to invite at-
tention to the fact that Crematories Nos. 1 and 2, aside from being
heavy and not readily transportable, require a certain amount of
skilled labor for their erection. Although 10 men working under
the supervision of the inventor can put together one of them in
about five hours, it does not follow that the same number of sold-
iers could accomplish the same result in the same time. Again, this
system, like all others submitted, demands constant and intelligent
attention in order to accomplish the proper operation of any one of
them.

In the opinion of the Board, none of those mentioned above
meet all of the conditions of troops in the field, as well or as
8
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
economically as the apparatus recommended by this Board in its re-
port of December 28, 1898. We believe that the apparatus therein
described is much easier of construction, far more readily trans-
portable and capable of effecting the same results in an equally
satisfactory manner as to the disposal of excreta. For large hospitals
or permanent camps, the Smith Crematory, if intelligently managed,
will suffice for the destruction of both excreta and garbage and for
such purposes we believe that it may be recommended.
